pros: Flexibility. The only pro I can think of aside from the staff I work with (and the clients) is this job is very flexible! You can adjust your schedule to whatever you need to do during the day.
cons: The biggest con is pay. You work SO HARD and are constantly multitasking.. It's one thing to work a job where you "go, go, go" all day long, but to work a job where it's "go, go, go" using your brain, which uses the most energy is mentally draining. You problem solve when you counsel, when clients cancel and you're scrambling to figure out who you can see to replace that person, making your own schedule, calling all the parents, figuring out how many hours of service you've billed for the week. It's just a lot. Not getting paid much makes it feel not worth it many days. Especially when you don't get raises or every few years when do give raises, they are small.

pros: Its a nonprofit, so your time there potentially counts towards the ten loan forgiveness. I liked most of my co-workers a lot.
cons: When I first started with centerstone, we were competitive. Everyone wanted to work there and they treated the employees so well. 3.5 years ago, upper management at the top level changed, and everything completely shifted. Everything has become completely numbers driven, and all I ever hear is "employees need to earn their salary". We are constantly being double and triple booked, booked up for months out with no choice in saying we cant accept new clients, so we have people being seen once every 6-8 weeks, some of whom are suicidal. This has been brought up as an ethical issue, in which upper management shrugs. The pay is far below average, and we are constantly being overloaded with clients. We were told that lunch breaks do not count towards out work hours for the day, and paperwork must be done during work hours which is impossible, given how long the new online system takes. A careplan takes 45-60 minutes to complete alone. The new system was launched prior to completion due to the fiscal year starting, and it constantly has errors. Everyone is always being sent emails about how behind they are in paperwork and billing errors and careplan incompletion because the system doesnt notify us as it should. We are not given any professional development time or paid trainings or ceu's. We were told if we wanted to attend a conference to use our pto. Nothing between clinics is consistent. The duties of a supervisor or therapist at one clinic varies from others. There were inconsistencies amongst pay, as well as job expectations even at our own clinic. Recently the higher ups did a MASS LAYOFF, and let go several employees across multiple offices due to budgeting and financial issues. Employees were given NO WARNING, and told to turn in their things immediately. No goodbye party, no transition sessions for clients, nothing. This company doesn't care about their employees or their clients and it's evident in their actions.

pros: The insurance wasn’t horrible I guess?

-Pay, I received my lowest offer here out of college. 
-Supervisors were very vindictive, especially if you challenged them.   
-The culture at the Columbus location was pretty toxic. Medical staff conflicted with clinical staff constantly. The medical staff (LPNs, NPs and MD) felt they were better than the clinical staff (therapists, recovery coaches, engagement specialists, office professionals). When drug reps would provide lunch for the agency, the clinical staff had to wait until medical staff were through eating before clinical staff could eat. It felt very divided amongst departments, instead of being part of a team. 
-The supervision was terrible. I felt like I was in a therapy session where my clinical supervisor wanted to know personal information about me instead of focusing on practice and my work with clients.  I felt like many boundaries were crossed in those “clinical supervision session”, I found myself feeling very uncomfortable  many many times when I had clinical supervision .

job_title: Family Support Specialist in Indianapolis, IN
pros: This job is very flexible, and you make your own schedule, so you don't have to miss out on a lot of things that are important to you, such as your children's activities. You can also work remotely if need be.
cons: You play so many roles, and expectations are high. Making your own schedule is great for flexibility but requires a lot of time setting up appointments, rescheduling, organizing, and making sure you have enough people scheduled to bill for the day . You are expected to transport clients in your vehicle and use your personal cell phone to contact contacts, so they all have your phone number and can access you anytime. I have asked for a company cell phone several times. It is so hard to separate home from work when clients share your vehicle with you and have your cell number. Since you do so much throughout the day, it is mentally draining: making your schedule, answering phones, counseling clients, playing taxi, dealing with school staff/parents/landlords/etc for the client, and all the computer work is something completely separate im not going into.The pay just isn't enough. That is why the turnover rate is so high! There is so much pressure to have so many billable hours a day, but the pay isn't worth it.

pros: Most positions offer very flexible scheduling which is great, they offer wellness reimbursement, and it can be a very rewarding job if you like working with people and making a difference.
cons: Well to begin, Centerstone is so desperate because they have such a high turn over that they've actually asked employees to come to this site and write positive reviews and feedback, they've also began offering incentives for referring friends (instead of just paying current employees better). Centerstone underpays it's employees (often typical in this type of work) but they also set productivity levels which are extremely difficult to meet. If you do not meet these productivity levels you are threatened with repercussion and possible termination. In turn you are always stressed out and fearing that you could lose your job for something that is often times out of your control. (clients ALWAYS cancel, making it impossible to meet productivity) Management, aside from a couple amazing bosses, is terrible. They don't encourage you or reinforce you for doing well, terrible morale.  Employees are constantly leaving and again, there is a very very high turn over rate, in my two years I don't think they have ever been fully staffed.  The employees who have made it this long are always shocked when a new employee makes it longer than 3-6 months. When I began at Centerstone I had full intentions of getting the $500 productivity bonus every month to supplement for the low pay, I have never received the bonus except in my first 2 months when my productivity was lowered for training... so DO NOT plan for this like I did upon accepting the position.

pros: This company does provide benefits to its clients, in some cases. There are some caring and talented people on the staff, and they do some good.
cons:
The biggest negative is that the company is dishonest about its function. You will be trained to meet clients where they are, and to center your work on clients, and that the mission of the organization is to change lives for the better. This is not the way the company really operates. Staff are pressured to bill, bill, bill above all else. Client care is not the priority.

So, if you choose to work at this company, be aware that you will be in a position to learn in an immersive setting. You will also be subjected to an emotionally and physically unhealthy work environment. Self-care is nothing but empty words - they do not provide an environment that is conducive, and it doesn't take long to see it. 

Management in the company is old-school, top-down, and corporate in the worst ways. They feign interest in the opinions and needs of the staff, but rarely hear anything that contradicts their own thinking.  If you want confirmation of these thoughts, simply read through the other reviews and then read the defensive, condescending responses. That is how they roll.

job_title: Peer Support Specialist in Bloomington, IN
pros: I love this company for many reasons! The hours are flexible,  they offer time off and promote self care. The company really seems to care about employees and are very trusting. When I was sick and brought in a Doctors statement I was told this was not necessary. I have never worked for a company that was genuinely concerned about their employees and are always there to offer support.  What sets my review apart from others is that at one point I was a client of Centerstone.  I have seen both sides of this organization. From a client as well as an employee.  As a client I can tell you that Centerstone saved my life and as an employee they gave me a chance to give back.  I love this company and this is the best company I have ever worked for!
cons: I have nothing negative to say about Centerstone. I have worked here for three years and all my supervisors have been wonderful.  My experience has been nothing but good.

review_title: The company is not employee friendly and only cares about making money.
pros: Employees work here because of their desire to help the clients.The employees really care about the clients.
cons: The Management and clinic manager are awful, very demanding and constantly pushing productivity on the employees to make more money. Management gets big bonuses and the employees get nothing. The pay is below average and raises are not given yearly and if they do give a raise its not even 3%. Management cuts jobs and puts more work on the remaining employees, but gives them no additional compensation. The pay is so bad that some employees are eligible for food stamps. Some employees can barely pay their bills. Turnover rate is horrible.

pros: Centerstone is mission-driven to serve those with severe mental illness who have the least social supports. Everyone brings their best to work in an effort to help others and it is a honor to be a part of the professional team here.  Medical providers work with a team of social workers and counselors to help each patient achieve their life goals and overcome their most difficult struggles.  The people I work with in my location are positive, fun, uplifting, compassionate and professional.
cons: I don't like that I can't put my credentials on my wall.  It can be difficult to obtain prior medical records and recent lab work results. Obtaining complete hospital discharge summaries at time of follow-up appointment is a statewide problem. I wish there were more specific forms of psychotherapy available to patients, such as Dialectical Behavioral Therapy or EMDR or couples therapy, etc.

review_title: A great organization to work for!!
pros: I really enjoy the people I work alongside. Everyone is so welcoming and friendly. It also feels really great to know you are helping people in the community that are in need of help. You get to play a major role in crushing the stigma of behavioral health while seeing the results and effects that help can have on our clients.
cons: In some roles there are growth areas, but in certain departments there is not a lot of room to grow into higher positions. This doesn't mean you can't get great experience. You still get to learn a lot and are directly connected to those at the top, but you won't be able to climb any ladders.

review_title: ACT Team - Challenging and Never a Dull Moment
pros:
Lots of interesting & wonderful clients.
Excellent team atmosphere and support.
Weekly team meetings to discuss challenges and strategies for helping consumers.
cons:
Case loads may be small (usually around a dozen consumers), but the challenges can often be rather difficult.
Meeting weekly quotas and documenting adequately when you compensate for drive time can be near impossible within a 40 hour work week, but you are not permitted overtime unless you go over your quota.  A number of team members worked off the clock to meet the quotas.
Working one on one in clients' homes is sometimes dangerous, and it's not unheard of for team members, counselors, etc, to suffer physical attacks by clients.

The two day safety training is not nearly enough to help employees respond as instructed automatically when attacked.  I was lucky to have hand-to-hand military training to fend off an attack in the home.

pros: Individual client based program. Work we do with the Addiction population. Life skills we teach. Changing Individual lives one step at a time. Health and wellness. Working to help clients with health care, budgeting, support systems. Help them to see their strengths and how strong they are during crisis. Help clients become independent
cons: Loosing a client when they are not ready for services and who have a hard time getting clean from drugs. When I cannot find resources for their needs or my hands are tied. team work. Time for treatment team meetings. There are times when having communication issues between employees and management. There is a need for more compassion at times, employees do not understand the reason we have clients are due to mental issues. They don't understand behaviors and management automatically think clients are manipulating and do not trust employees critical thinking and we loose the client.

pros:
Excellent place to learn about behavioral health and substance abuse practices. Staff are friendly. Vacation time (if you are able to take off).
Use this place to obtain knowledge and then move on to better organizations.
cons:
Poor leadership and management.  Poor morale and constantly understaffed due to high turn over.  Just look on Indeed for all the vacant position as evidence. 
Centerstone of Florida  has an extremely poor reputation within the community.  I'm surprised they haven't had their license revoked as well.  
They treat employees like they are disposable.  It is sad, but there is no loyalty and most employees feel they are always about to get fired.  Running an organization with fear tactics is not advisable.  
The organization went downhill after the affiliation with Centerstone. Since then,  there has been more disconnect and disorganization.

pros: I worked with Centerstone on a grant team outside of the typical position you might find working with this organization. Overall, the work this organization does is amazing. The communities they work with really go the extra mile to help those that are in need. Like most work in a social service type of environment with special populations, the work can be very challenging. The most important thing to remember is to have a good work/life balance, and to ask for help or advice when needed. Upper management in  this organization really strive to help their employees have the best working experience they can.
cons: Work can be  challenging and mentally exhausting. Pay isn't as competitive as working in other field, but if the passion to help those in need is what you want to be doing with your life, than Centerstone is a great place to be able to do that!

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Bradenton, FL
pros: Quality staff, real teamwork, effective management, opportunity to grow and advance professionally.   Usually some extra hours to pick up but no real pressure to do so. cons: I hear the health insurance plan is not that great. Fortunately I am a veteran and go through the VA so this not an issue for me.  Another thing is, if you are a great employee but stay in the same entry level position, your pay will not increase much beyond what other new hires get for same position.  That being said, there are opportunities for advancement but one has to get the education, etc., and ask for what they want.

review_title: Need not apply @ Centerstone of Indiana
pros: Clients.  Some co-workers. Benefits (retirement very poor due to low wages).  But the CEO has a plane!
cons:
1) No work life balance.
2).  Couldn’t pay my bills, but helped others (clients) pay their bills.
3).   Limited skilled supervision
4). Supervisors are pressured by government contracts/grants.
5). Interventions are determined by grants, not according to clinical discretion nor what the client needs.
6). Concurrent documentation doesn’t allow for real rapport nor therapeuic relationships.
7). Nobody is paid their worth.  But the CEO has a personal plane.  (Non-profit?)
8).   “Community based care” means not partnering with other organizations to share resources.
9) New, excited, and young professionals are scooped up early in their time at Centerstone due to enthusiasm and “promise.” This leads to burn out, compassion fatigue, and high turnover.  It’s not because they like you.  You’ll regret it.

The relationships and I build within the organization as well as referral sources are valuable and withstanding.  Management and lateral co-workers, as well as staff are supportive and hard working with the vision of creating and environment for clients' growth within the communities we are embedded.

job_title: Behavioral Health Specialist in Columbus, IN
pros: Not a single one in all honesty

pros:

Company adds more work on employees, but without any extra compensation. Company claims to be losing money, but is always buying other mental health companies that are going bankrupt in other states. 
Company is more focus on buying other companies out of state, than keeping their current employees.

pros: Centerstone TRULY lives up to it noble purpose.  I've never worked with so many caring people who go out of their way to help people.  Personally, my supervisor, all the way up to the COO is understanding and "family friendly" promoting life/work balance.

review_title: Great working with kids, but pay is abysmal and rapidly decreasing.

This means we are not paid for the countless hours of filling out paperwork, talking with parents, collaborating with teachers, attending meetings, etc. And now we do not get paid mileage reimbursement which makes it difficult during summer when we typically drive to client homes.

review_title: May be good in some areas
job_title: Behavioral Health Technician in Bloomington, IN
pros: Good trainings, opportunities to grow (supposedly).  Seems they are doing good in some areas.
cons: I worked in a residential treatment facility, and overall I found their treatment of clients to be very old fashioned.  Not holistic health: talk to "the doctor" and take a cocktail of pills.  Staff did not model healthy lifestyles.  Pay was not good considering the amount of responsibilities and stress caused by the position.  Depressing environment.

review_title: Wish I had a more positive report!
pros: Challenging and interesting opportunity to reduce suffering. As long as I bring in enough money they leave me alone. Caring people work here.
cons: Immense pressure to generate revenue. Disorganized, too many supervisors, terrible communication, high turnover. So many programs no one knows what all is going on in our location. There is no list of all the groups that are offered, no consolidated information on what services are available or who qualifies, etc.  Who is hired, who changed jobs? Who is on my enormous caseload? Not important, they are just enlightened about my revenues.

job_title: Family Support Specialist in Richmond, IN
pros: The scheduling is very flexible. My supervisor truly cares about me as a person. Working in community mental health is tough, but she makes it fun. The clients are wonderful and make every day rewarding, even though every day can simultaneously be challenging! My co-workers are my family away from home and I feel appreciated for the work I put in to Centerstone. Additionally, there are so many opportunities for career advancement within Centerstone. Even if you don't want to go back to school for your Master's degree, you can find so many different avenues to take if you need a break from front-line work.
cons:
To start off with, I have been quite surprised by some of the other reviews I've seen on here. I received the same E-mail encouraging staff to leave reviews on this site that everyone else received, and it was not in any way asking us to lie or paint an inaccurately positive picture of our jobs. These are anonymous, so no one is getting paid to leave a positive review and no supervisor can put anyone's job on the line for not reviewing. I'd encourage anyone reading through these to critically consider some of the reviews on here to determine if they really make sense or if they are simply the disgruntled employee that any organization has.  I'd also hope that anyone who is as dissatisfied with their job as some of these people seem to be would simply leave and find something that's a better fit. 

My personal main con is that working in community mental health isn't for everyone. It's hard work and no matter what CMHC you work for, you're never going to make as much money as you deserve. This, however, isn't due to any CEO getting rich or some conspiracy theory put in place by upper management, it's due to the abysmal reimbursement rates for mental health services. 

Hitting billing goals isn't easy, but it's do-able. I hit my incentive with some regularity and I know many others who earn it even more often. Again, I would say if this is something that feels unreasonable to you, this field just may not be a great fit for you.

review_title: Delivering Care that Changes People's Lives
pros: Working at Centerstone allows you to deliver care that changes people's lives in on a daily basis.  The organization is regularly working towards developing opportunities to better serve our communities which allows for varied opportunities for staff and great training and experience.  The work we do is important and allows staff the honor to serve clients and be a part of their journey of recovery.
cons: Work at Centerstone requires a daily hustle in order to meet the high need of our communities.  The space in which we operate also makes change a constant; resulting in the need for regular flexibility and adaptation.

pros: They are doing a great job to be more organized with training new therapists. I like the flexibility of the job and the time off the school based schedule provides. My supervisors are helpful and supportive.
cons: The pay is low... very low... even when you factor in what I could be making if I worked more days (less days worked with school based) it's still less than other companies that are also non profit working in mental health. SO LOW.

pros: I have been with Centerstone for over 11 years and I continue to learn and grow with each day.  Knowing that we really are changing people's lives is a huge part of job fulfillment for me.  Centerstone has many opportunities for growth and will also provide financial assistance for those who want to pursue their degree.  I can honestly say I never dread going into the office and that feels great!
cons: You need the compassion for mental health.  This is not a con,  however, Centerstone is not the place for you if you do not have a passion to help others either indirectly or directly.

review_title: A lot of it depends on who your program/supervisor is. . .
job_title: Community Based Worker Program Unspecified in Nashville, TN
pros: fun coworkers, opportunities to bonus, training potential (great for people starting out in their career).
cons:
productivity expectations- you are expected to make it even if there are things outside your control like no shows, sickness, low caseload, etc.
Workers don't get raises and some have been at same pay rate for 5 yrs.  
I'm looking to leave because I don't trust my supervisor or her supervisor.

job_title: Director of Online Communications in Nashville, TN
pros:
Having just completed my first year of employment with Centerstone, the pros:
Was hired despite being an older applicant (or maybe because of it).
Was given tools to launch in new position but then left to work without interference.
Was consistently given praise for doing a good job.
Was, after some temporary renovations, given a nice environment in which to work.
Was encouraged to foster a company culture of camaraderie through monthly social events.
cons: The only cons I've experienced in my first year were from my own growing pains, going from working in one field to this more corporate experience. But in time, having found my footing, those have dissipated.

job_title: Child and Family Therapist in Muncie, IN
pros:
-All of my coworkers are helpful and friendly; we all work towards helping the clients and advocating for their needs. There's almost no office drama. 
-Supportive supervisors. I've never worked in an office with such supportive supervisors who are clear in their communication and expectations. I've had two supervisors (Taylor Stephens and Stacey VanPelt) attend a DCS Team Meeting to help advocate for client and provider safety. 
-Flexibility.
-Focus on clients.
cons:
-No set hours.
-Moderate amount of paperwork.
-We're social workers/therapists working with impoverished populations; we won't be making a fortune here.

review_title: Until Centerstone changes, please treat yourself better
pros: The only pro currently available is PTO*
cons:
*However, Centerstone does not adjust your productivity when taking care of yourself. If you are in administration position, this does not effect you yet for those of us who work with clients day-in and day-out, this impacts us and our own mental health by being reprimanded and written up if we do not meet our productivity for having taken time off.  Getting under 90% means you're getting a corrective action even if that is 89%.

Recently Centerstone employees were asked to complete this survey in order to make Centerstone look better; Recently there have been perfect scores correlating with this request which do not match the atmosphere of the business or the model Centerstone management claims to have to potential employees such as you.

I am a full-time employee with Centerstone. The current productivity requirements cause a great deal of stress and employee loss; additionally, most rehab specialists are expected to carry 25+ (pushing 30+) clients on average per staff which does not provide quality client care or "Delivering care that changes people's lives" as their motto states.  Instead, it keeps clients at Centerstone for long term by providing minimal services at the cost of their mental health and yours.  Furthermore due to the "State of Emergency" in which Centerstone finds itself in, staff are expected to take on additional roles (*with out* compensation or adjustments) and are held accountable when they are not able to meet their 'days to chart' in a 40/hr week (see above).

The pay scale is beatable by other employers whether for profit or non-for profit; within state or in surrounding states. Additionally, living in Bloomington, IN we have the highest living cost of living in Indiana and Centerstone does not pay to reflect. We are considered the working-poor.

When you communicate with your management, they say and pretend to take your objective views and concerns into consideration yet do nothing about it and if anything, do the complete opposite in which your counselling advised them of.  Shoot -
 - even the HR Staff themselves do not support you! and will undermine you and make you feel worse for having attempted to constructively address your concerns to improve the quality and worth of the company yet instead, chose to have parties as if it is the real problem why we lose employees all the time. 

The parties do not retain staff; however, those few staff who work together keep each other afloat for the sake of our clients in this hostile atmosphere they promote. Yet due to the current atmosphere, you can not form work relationships with your staff as a result of pressure from meeting productivity, days-to-chart requirements and trying to keep your 25+ clients okay.

Turnover with this company is extremely high due to these reasons listed. If you are a social worker, please treat yourself with respect that you deserve.  You deserve to be happy and treated with respect; you won't find it here at Centerstone.

pros: helping clients in their most vulnerable times, helping people rebuild their lives, flexibility with work schedule, overtime pay always available (due to understaffing), learned a lot - both positive and negative
cons: horrible management, employees gossip and don't support one another,  lack of training, micromanagement from corporate bosses who aren't on site, understaffed, extremely inappropriate boundaries between employees and clients with no enforcement

pros: Supportive coworkers, no work after hours
cons: Worked for 9 months & only accrued 6 1/2 days of PTO after days were taken for snow & forfeited after giving 1 month's notice of resignation,  pay does not increase with productivity, no room for advancement, took 2+ months for insurance to kick in & 7+ months to get an ID badge (even then my name was misspelled), worked holidays like MLK Day and Good Friday, no windows in claustrophobic workspace, constantly harassed by angry patients because of the high turnover rate for therapists, emails ignored for months on end by case managers in my department

pros: If you love working with people there isn't a job more rewarding then helping people who truly need it and for the most part appreciate it.
cons:
The pay could be better but I don't know of too many jobs were you are paid what you are really worth.
Since this job is working with people sometimes it is hard to take off work on the spur of the moment because you have to make sure that you cancel your appointments with everyone first.

pros:
-This company is really focused on helping people! They have an employee-supported fund to help clients and most staff bend over backwards to help their clients.
- My co-workers are awesome! I have never worked with a more supportive, friendly, and fun bunch of people. I enjoy working with people who are creative and caring.
- Management seems to be working hard to listen to staff regularly and they do as much as they can to make the work environment and our experiences as positive as possible. 
- The benefits are incredible, especially considering that this is a non-profit agency!
- There are lots of opportunities to move into positions that fall within my interest areas. There are lots of opportunities for horizontal moves for staff who have specific areas of interest, and there are opportunities to move vertically as well, for those interested in advancing their careers, leadership positions, etc. Staff in my office are encouraged to do what they love and with all the options we have, it's easy to do just that. 
- There are LOTS of locations, so even if I were to move to another county, or a neighboring state, I would have the opportunity to transfer to another office if I want.
- My hours are flexible and my supervisors have always been very understanding of my needs. If I am sick, just need a day off, or even if I have something come up at the last minute and have to take off without prior notice, I have never been penalized. My supervisor encourages me to focus on taking care of myself and my family and allows me to work around other obligations as long as I am getting my work done.
-We have the opportunity to earn monthly incentives for exceeding billing expectations and while I personally don't get it every month, it is entirely possible to earn it and a lot of my co-workers get it all the time.
cons:
- As a non-profit, Centerstone does have some limitations with pay and benefits, though they are fairly competitive in the field and with other non-profits, so this isn't really that much of a con, given the type of organization this is. 
- On paper, our productivity expectations are actually pretty reasonable, and from experience with other agencies, they are actually a little lower than what I have had to deal with in the past. However, in reality, it is sometimes a struggle to meet productivity expectations because we also depend on clients to be engaged, which can be difficult, especially given the population we work with. 
- The number of staff in my department has grown considerably since I started, so space can be an issue when we all get together. We are definitely outgrowing our facilities quickly which has created a bit of a headache, especially when some offices are getting new buildings, while others have to just deal with space issues. 
-Our charting system can be extremely annoying and difficult to use if we are working off-site.

review_title: A good place to get started...
job_title: Therapist and Research in Nashville, TN
pros: Centerstone was my 1st job out of grad school. They have great values and mission. I will always appreciate that I worked at Centerstone and it helped my career. All of my successful professional skills came from working at Centerstone. I worked in multiple clinics and structures so I got to see more than some. You get to see everything, good and bad, and you learn how to work under various pressure and constraints and still be successful. I most enjoyed my fellow coworkers. They were all hardworking and truly made my time there more enjoyable.
cons:
The pressure for clinical staff can be insurmountable at times with no structured administrative time, productivity standards and  community mental health frequent no shows. It's especially difficult to appreciate time off without feeling that you are potentially punished by not working every day of every month.
The management doesn't always seem to care and at times actively work against their staff which creates a tense and toxic work environment. Sometimes management is not always honest with their staff I think that management also has some high level of expectations that can be a bit unrealistic causing staff to not get the adequate level of support when needed. New staff sink or swim and old staff get used to figuring it out on their own. Sometimes you don't see or hear from management at all until something is wrong. 
There is absolutely no real quality control as to what is happening in sessions or work with clients. Much of what people do is inconsistent with quality care and effective practice according to research and it appears that Centerstone is not able to manage this. 
Financially, Centerstone seems unstable, laying off chunks of staff while rapidly expanding to other states. This happened a few times during my time there.

In some Centerstone environments there seems to be budgets for fun things such as birthday celebrations while in other environments, there seems to be a void in anything that could add morale or enjoyment to hard working staff.

pros: centerstone is a great place to work....it is rewarding to help clients and communities and my colleagues and the benefits are awesome. the job has a lot of  flexibility and a very good incentive system--so if you do a good job, you can make more money. I find upper management to be very supportive
cons: it is a difficult job, but that's the nature of this field....also, sustainable funding for some services is hard to find

pros: Good place to get your foot in the door of the mental health/social work field. Especially if you are trying to figure out if you want to go back to school, or transition into a different field.  Everyone is pretty nice and the company is diverse. Managers willing to help you be more understanding, and they are pretty understanding themselves. Ability to gain a lot of perspective people and their circumstances. Ability to gain insight and experience with connecting to people, fostering relationships, and growing as an individual. Flexible work schedule 7:30-4:00, 8:00-4:30. 8:30-5:00. Helping clients and getting to know them feels rewarding. Doing a good deed everyday by helping those less fortunate.
cons: Started out good, but after you have been there for awhile, you start to see the major flaws in this organization. Compensation for the work, high turnover, difficult patients, they care about quantity of calls/contacts rather than the quality of help you are providing (which only started about 4-5 months ago...you have to make certain number of calls and contacts per month/week and will be written up depending on how close you are to said number). Managers checking in on the metrics a lot now, micromanaging, and the compensation and incentives don't compare to other metric driven industries. Lots of change and ambiguity in what we are actually suppose to help client's with...which can also be a pro, due to being able to talk to them about whatever you want, but it is not very structured. Can bring home a whole lot of emotional baggage. Not a whole lot of fun team building exercises or incentives. No room for growth without going back to school.  Also, the other staff members dislike care coordinators due to unknown reasons, but have complained to management about us multiple times. One of the most recent complaints is about food and shared lunches, how Care Coordinators should not get any and only the therapists and med providers should...petty stuff right there. Also, due to the metrics that became in place, it feels like a lot of cold calling due to client's not answering phones.

review_title: Racism runs thick! Overworked with little pay and no help!
pros: Great group of coworkers which made it easier to go to work each day.
cons: No transparency or trust in the department. Low man on the totem pole is constantly overlooked while others are grossly overpaid to do nothing. Overworked loyal employees get no help and the pay rate is laughable.

pros: Centerstone offers multiple opportunities for personal growth and for flexibility in work schedule. I have been with this company since I graduated and this year Centerstone made significant adjustment to salaries above what my peers say they make at other companies. I love our mission and appreciate our CARES program that allow us to meet vital needs of our most vulnerable clients. I have the latitude to use evidence practices in client centered and team based approaches.
cons: As with any community mental health facilities funding changes, documentation requirements can be overwhelming at times to manage.

review_title: Vision and Intent is Commendable, but Underfunded
pros: Centerstone wants to provide high quality services and supports.  Majority of staff really care about their clients and the work that they do.  Opportunities to learn and provide innovating services.
cons: Current funding streams for Non Profits are not sufficient to support market value salaries.  Industry payment system is in disruption, requiring system and staffing re-organization, leading to overburdening workloads to facilitate transitions.

pros: I feel that I help my community by working here. Centerstone's mission and purpose are in line with my own values. The teams are extremely close here...my co-workers are also my friends and we support each other in everything.
cons: It can be busy/stressful, and the pay is not out of this world but the rewards far outweigh these trade-offs.

job_title: Training Specialist in West Frankfort, IL
pros: Paid time off and holidays aren't too bad. Currently have BCBS insurance and the premium is low.
cons: I have worked for this company for over 15 years and only make $12.09/hr.  This is not an acceptable, livable wage.  A union employee can only go as far as the union openings will let you. Otherwise you try to climb the management ladder and its not easy.

pros:
I had a Great Practicum experience.  
Helpful Co workers
cons:
Mobile Therapy experience hours didn't count towards Licensure.  You are expected to attend Case Management supervision and complete Case Management responsibilities in addition to your Therapist responsibilities,  which increase the ability to bill more per client, increase your caseload, and productivity. Productivity is the bottom line, $$$. 
Case management supervision doesn't count towards your LPC Licensure supervision needed because case management meetings are not facilitated by an approved supervisor. This means that your earning two to four less signatures per month needed, and it will take you twice as long to obtain the signatures that you need for LPC Licensure.

pros: The children are so helpless and vulnerable, I loved getting to work with them all. I feel like I made a huge impact on their lives. The work itself was rewarding.
cons:

Vice President

cons: Supervisor was hard to get in contact with, questions could hopefully be answered by other staff. Supervisor was also inconsistant with answers when you could get in contact. Job never felt secure even though I had great reviews.

review_title: Centerstone - the place to be if you want to delivery care that changes people's lives
job_title: Human Resources Director in West Frankfort, IL
pros: Working with great people committed to quality community services.  Working alongside people who care.  Developing culture that is transforming into a place that recruits, maintains, develops and grows great employees.
cons: Current ability to competitively recruit alongside for profits

pros: It's a job.  Enjoy working with the population. Love my co-workers. Great supervisor.  Best perk is being able to work from home.
cons: Doesn't pay enough for the amount of work. Caseloads of 75+. Poor benefits. Lack of caring of upper management. Lack of recognition. No bereavement pay.

review_title: Believe in the mission of your work at Centerstone!
pros: Centerstone is a place of integrity, where people are committed to offering life-changing services to others. As healthcare changes over time for a myriad of reasons, Centerstone works to ensure the best services for its clients and the most support for its employees.
cons: Sometimes it takes a long time to implement changes because the organization is so large.

pros:
You get to create your own schedule.
The coworkers in similar positions are cool. 
That's honestly it. It's terrible.
cons:
Management does not care about its employees at all.
They will give you an oversized caseload and multiple positions but won't compensate you fairly. 
It is incredibly easy to get burnt out. 
The turn over is incredibly high. Everytime someone leaves, they just disperse the case load amongst the remaining case workers, which leads someone else to leave and the cycle repeats itself. 
They preach "self care" and say you can take a day off when you need one, but then will get angry with you when you dont meet your production quota. 
Production quotas are not changed to reflect PTO or clients that do no show. 
You will work your fingers to the bone for nothing. 
The trainings they give you are not helpful. You will have to learn everything on the fly. Working here is like being shoved into a pit of vipers and then scolded when you get bit or request assistance. 
They "give you" a decent amount of PTO, but thethey neglect to tell you that any bereavement, sick days, or medical leave is taken from that PTO. They don't offer any assistance otherwise.

review_title: A system that sets you up for failure
pros: I have increased my skill set and gained great experience with working with at-risk adults. My schedule is flexible and I get to be a direct part of the treatment of mental and substance use disorders. I love my clients and get to make a difference. I get to support and empower others by advocating for them, helping them access resources, and be there for them in ways that other agencies and organizations cannot.
cons: Unfortunately, the cons heavily outweigh the pros in this organization. That is very sad because my pros are pretty amazing. Rarely do I feel like my above pros are actually reality in my job and in myself because cons of the organization overpower the reasons the job could be so great. Centerstone's system of "productivity" sets up one for failure. Due to poor management, lack of general care and support for their employees, and a complete disregard when employees voice their concerns, Centerstone is not a positive place to work. Add that to the already existing pressure, heaviness, and workload of the job, and you're looking at a complete mess. I am underpaid and overworked. That is to be expected in this field, but my main disappointment is how little I am valued by my organization. For reasons that I cannot control (getting sick, clients not showing up for appointments, etc) I have never, not once, met the hours of care standard. I passively aggressively get condemned for this, and I go to work with anxiety every day. And no real, ethical solutions are offered to me to fix the "problem." And I have a lot of responsibilities that directly affect people's lives that I'm juggling, but that's not considered by management. I bend over backwards constantly to make sure my clients get the support they need, I encourage them, coordinate with other providers, and I pour out my heart and soul because I am passionate about people. That has never been valued, recognized, or reinforced. All my superiors care about is how much "revenue" I produce. I see coworkers (and myself) often sacrificing quality in their work with clients so that they can be in good standing with their bosses. In turn, clients end up not getting the boundaries they need to be independent because the employees are so worried about not making their hours of care. And I know I'm not alone. Every coworker I have talked with has expressed this.  All of this leads to one conclusion in my mind: an organization that does not care about their employees does not care about their clients. At that point, what's the reason for the organization even existing if they are totally forgetting about the reason they do what they do in the first place?

pros: Provided opportunity to move up in 2009.  Was a place where demands were high but rewards were worthwhile.  Centerstone is a community mental health agency which has the potential to teach new therapists a great deal, but burnout can be very high.
cons: Salary was not keeping up with demands, bogged down in paperwork, potentially difficult productivity standards

review_title: Strong mission, growth-oriented organization, focus on clinical excellence and collaboration.
pros: Visionary leadership, opportunities for clinical training and development, supportive teams, people at all levels of organization really care about clients, staff and our communities.
cons: Rapid change associated with State and Federal budgetary challenges. Benefits are OK but not as generous as they used to be.

review_title: Highly recommended for place of employment
pros: There is an amazing work environment with dedicated staff who are pleasant and supportive.  We get extremely helpful guidance to ensure we are providing the best services to our clients to help them reach their goals and objectives.
cons: I have no complaints or cons to list.

review_title: Currently, an outpatient therapist;  formerly (for about 11 years, a clinic manager
pros: good people to work with in clinics:  friendly;  client-oriented;  ethical;  good support from management on tough calls (disorderly clients, therapeutic decisions made with their input, etc.);  good benefits;  I've been with them since 1995 because I enjoy working with this company
cons: Like any company, there is the occasional "pickle" to deal with.

pros: It’s a nonprofit that is ran like a for profit organization.  Very compassionate employees who truly care about their clients.  Great executive leadership team who cares about their employees and strive to make it a great place to work.
cons: Organization has grown quite a bit over the last 5 years or so they are playing catch-up with their systems.

pros: Experience I guess? They give employees the opportunity to switch positions within the company after 6 months (due to severe burnout). There are benefits included for full time employees. Flexible schedule.
cons:
All employees are overworked because the company is understaffed. Employees are expected to meet hours of care that are unattainable in a normal 40 hour work week. 
The pay is so horribly low (especially for the amount of work expected) that even working full time, in a position that requires a Bachelor's degree, employees barely fall above poverty line and qualify for most community low income services. None of upper management, or the CEO for that matter seem to have any issues with their pay, even though they are not the ones doing the essential work of the company and working with clients. 
The pay periods are set  by date (1-15th, 16th-end of month) so every paycheck comes on an 8th or 21st (or the nearest non weekend day), so can come on any day of the week.  Due to this pay period, each paycheck is a different amount, sometimes coming out hundreds of dollars lower than normal and leaving you even shorter on bills. I've heard this will be changing, but that was over a year ago. The people making these decisions don't have to worry about how they're going to make ends meet without regular consistent paychecks, while everyone else doing the actual work of the company are barely getting by. 
Due to staffing shortages/lack of qualified therapists, all employees are put in the position of being a therapist for clients, which is unethical and asking way too much of under-qualified employees. Employees are loaded with so many clients, there is no possible way to provide the "person centered care" the company claims to use.
PTO has to be earned through work time, and is earned at a very slow rate. All absences (sick days, bereavement etc) must be taken from your PTO time, leaving little to no actual PTO to take to keep that work/life balance they preach about.  
Mileage rates are incredibly low for the amount of driving and transporting clients that is required of the job. Mileage reimbursement does not cover the additional expenses of the wear your car will be receiving from the extensive driving, or any damage or soiling caused by clients. Employees are basically taxis for clients.

review_title: This job is ideal if you're getting licensed as LPC because they pay for supervision hours, but not for LMFT
job_title: School Based Therapist in Nashville, TN
pros: My supervision teams were great and I loved the children and faculty in the schools.
cons: Pay is so low and not sustainable at all. The work is long and requires a lot of self-care, but with the low income, self-care is hard to access.

job_title: Intensive In-home Therapist in Nashville, TN
pros:
Great people
Great clients
Flexible hours
Realistic number of clients (rare in this area)
